text: He's listening to the stretch call of a horse race, and h into it.
...at the top of the stretch it's  Cozy Girl in front with Backtrack  coming on... Cozy Girl by a length,  Backtrack closing...
Come on. Stay up there, Cozy Girl...
The CAMERA GRADUALLY pulls back to reveal that Roper is  driving his Trans Am across the Bay Bridge. HELICOPTER SH give a soaring view of the San Francisco skyline.
At the eighth pole it's Cozy Girl by  half a length... Backtrack closing...
Roper's police radio SQUAWKS.
One-one-four to Roper.
He picks up the radio.
Dig in, Cozy Girl... (into the radio) Roper go.
One-four, Roper. Code 2.C.P. 4th and  Grand.
It's Cozy Girl holding on... Cozy  Girl and Backtrack...
I'm en route. E.T.A. in five.
He tosses the radio down. Punches the accelerator.
Stay up there, Girl...
Cozy Girl in front by a neck... Now  a head...
Weaving through traffic on the bridge.
Where's the damn wire?!
Here comes the wire... and...  Backtrack gets up in the last jump.  Cozy girl a very game second.
SHIT!
The Trans Am streak off toward the city.

A hostage situation. Police barricades. Dozens of squad c ambulances, spectators, SWAT team. It's a stalemate. Rope Trans Am pulls to a stop at the barricades. He hops out,  weaves through the spectators and past the barriers. A FEMALE DETECTIVE, EIKO KIMURA, rushes up to him.
Hi, Roper.
Hi, Kimura. Where's the command post?
Kimura points to the diner in the middle of the block. Ro heads toward it. As they walk Kimura briefs him...
The suspect came in shortly after  the bank opened. Botched robbery. A  teller hit the silent alarm. He took  seven hostages. Shot one -- the guard.  He's still alive. So far he's asked  for...
...a car.
That's right, and a plane waiting at  the airport. If he doesn't...
...get 'em, he's going to start  shooting hostages in five minutes...
That's right.
What's the suspect's name?
Earl.
Across from the bank. This is where the "command post" is setup. About a dozen cops and the accompanying support st are here. Lieutenant SAMUEL BAFFERT is in charge. Roper  saunters in.
Hello, guys.
Hello, Roper. Glad you could join  us.
Roper walks over to the counter where Baffert is standing
Do we have a profile on Mr. Earl?
Baffert hands him a folder. Roper opens it.
This guy is no genius.
Roper scans the profile.
They're not usually graduate students.
SWAT wants to go in.
What's the rush? They haven't killed  anybody yet this week?
Roper refers to the folder.
We got a guy who's probably on drugs.  He's got a record of 459's and he  was busted on possession. But he's  never been busted on a major felony.  What's his demeanor?
Well he's a little fucking agitated --  he ripped the phone out.
I have to go face to face.
No -- you can't do that.

You got 7 hostages in there, 1 of  them's wounded -- We don't know how  bad it is -- The guy ripped the phone  out -- SWAT said he's got a gun to  the head of a female hostage. If  SWAT makes entry now, you're gonna  lose 1 hostage, maybe 2. I gotta go  in. Maybe I can see what's going on  in there.
I don't know.
He's never offed anybody. His rap  doesn't show any violence.
Not that we know of.
We don't know how much time we have.  If I can get in to talk to him --  maybe we won't lose anyone.
Maybe we can get a throw phone in  there.
SWAT says it's broken -- The perp in  the last situation rendered it  inoperable.
What do you mean?
He urinated on it and shorted out  the circuits.
We gonna stand here and talk about  it or let the guy in there bleed to  death. (beat... beat) Give me a dozen donuts.
Roper pulls out his gun and places it on the counter.
Roper eats the donut as he crosses toward the bank.

A team of two SWAT TEAM MEMBERS, FORBES IS A SPOTTER AND  MCCALL IS A SHARPSHOOTER. KEVIN MCCALL, is the one we're  interested in. He's 25 years old, handsome, all American. He's the best the SWAT team has. He crouches motionless, staring through the scope of his  rifle, watching as Roper calmly walks toward the bank.
What do you think he's got in the  bag?
Donuts.
You can't take a guy down with a  donut.

A tense situation. A wild-eyed, white punk, fuck-up of a  BANK ROBBER, EARL, is holding a pretty, young TELLER arou the neck with a cocked gun held to her temple. The other bank employees are cowering on the floor. A few are giving aid to the wounded bank guard who is half-cons and oozing blood from his side. Roper strolls right through the front door and walks towa Earl, very sociable.
Hi, Earl, I'm Scott Roper. Wanna  donut? I ate the glazed but there's  a bunch of chocolate and a --
Earl swipes the donuts out of Roper's hand and starts fri Roper for weapons with his free hand. The other hand stil has the gun poised at the young teller's head.
I'm a negotiator, Earl. I don't carry  a weapon.
Roper smiles reassuringly at the pretty teller. It seems help. Earl finishes patting Roper down, straightens back and puts his hand around the teller's neck.
Where's the car?
I need to get something straight  first.
Roper looks over at the other bank employees huddled on t floor.
Who's the manager?
A balding, middle-aged MAN sheepishly raises his hand.
I am.
Roper takes a step toward him.
When did you start keeping longer  hours?
Last spring.
Really! Because I've been thinking  of moving to this branch. It would  be really convenient for me --
HEY, SHUT UP!
Earl wags his gun against the Teller's ear.
Do you want me to start killing  people?!
Roper holds his hand up defensively.
It's my job to see that no one gets  killed, Earl... Including you.
Then where's my FUCKING car!
Earl is pouring sweat. His gun hand is shaking uncontroll
I'm getting it, Earl, but we have to  do this the right way.
Roper keeps his eyes locked on Earl. His voice is calm.
First I need you to point that gun  away from -- (to the teller) What's your name?
(voice trembling) Debbie...
Point the gun away from Debbie.
Debbie's brains are going to be  splattered all over the floor if I  don't see a car in five minutes!
Roper takes a long look at Earl. The guy is a hair trigge
Alright! But let's be clear about  one thing. If you kill someone, I  can't help you. The SWAT guys will  take you out.
Earl glances at the army of cop cars poised outside. Refl for a moment on the reality of the situation.
What are my chances of getting out  of here?
Roper calmly moves toward where the wounded guard is layi
Not bad. Last month, a guy robbed a  bank in Daly City...
Roper crouches down, smiles at the blurry-eyed guard.
How ya doin'?
The guard groans. He's not doing very well. Roper peels b the bloody handkerchief, takes a look. Winces.
(to Earl) ...Cops gave him a car, and he lost  them on the freeway.
Earl is encouraged by that.
Really?
Absolutely. Bank robbers are generally  your smartest criminals.
Roper looks directly into Earl's eyes.
He didn't kill anybody, though.
Roper bends over the guard.
This is gonna hurt.
He grabs the guard under the arms and starts dragging him across the floor. The guard MOANS piteously.
Hey, leave him alone. What are you  doing?
Roper keeps dragging the guard toward the front door.

It's part of my negotiator's oath.  If there's an injured party and I  can help them, I'm duty bound by my  oath to do that. You can shoot me if  you want, but the next negotiator in  here is going to tell you the same  thing.
Earl is unsure what to do, but he guesses an oath is an o He lets Roper drag the guard to the door.
I'll be right back, Earl. Point that  gun away from Debbie.
Earl compliantly moves the gun away from the teller's hea then re-thinks and jerks it back against her temple.
Roper drags the guard out the front door and deposits him the sidewalk. Two SWAT OFFICERS rush up to give aid. One them is Jennings.
(whispering to Jennings) Give me your gun.
(NOTE: The method of disarming Earl is still to be determ Jennings inconspicuously pulls his gun out and slips it t him. Roper quickly cocks it and shoves it in his waistban under his shirt and vest.
I haven't had to shoot anyone in  three years.
Why not keep the streak alive?
Because this strung-out junkie is  too stupid to get out of this without  killing somebody.
Earl watches Roper through the window. He can only see Ro back. He's getting very agitated.
(yelling) HEY, WHAT THE FUCK ARE YOU DOING OUT  THERE!
The two cops hustle off with the wounded guard, and Roper calmly walks back into the bank. Stops about five paces f Earl.
As a rule, I need one hostage released  as show of good faith.
Roper glances at Debbie. Gun pressed against her head. Te start rolling down her cheeks. She's being tremendously b
Give me Debbie.
Earl squeezes the gun even tighter against the side of he head.
Take the old guy.
The other hostages watch this exchange tensely.
The Old Guy? What kind of show of  faith is that? I want Debbie.
Am I gettin' the car?
You're gettin' the car.
Earl thinks about it, his gun hand twitching. He points a two of the female employees cowering against the counter.
Take them.
Roper decides that this is the best he's going to get.
You two, leave.
The two women don't need any extra encouragement. They ju up and rush out the front door.
McCall and Forbes watch through their rifle scopes as the two released hostages are whisked away by uniformed cops.
This guy is good.
That's what they say.
That was fine, Earl. Now I'm going  to get your car.
Roper turns around and walks toward the front door. He st and looks over his shoulder.
Oh, there's one last thing.
Earl looks like he's right on the edge.
What?!
You want a convertible or hardtop?
Earl thinks about that for a beat...
Hardtop.
Roper turns around, starts walking again. He keeps his ey focused on the reflection of Earl in the front window of bank.
(without turning around) Manual or automatic?
Automatic.
You got it.

In one swift motion, Roper turns, aims and FIRES!... One SHOT. It tears into Earl's shoulder. One inch from  Debbie's neck. Earl is blown back against the counter. De shrieks at the top of her lungs. SWAT guys pour in from every entrance. YELLING for everyb to "GET DOWN"! Pointing guns. They pounce on Earl.
I give up! I give up!
Roper goes to Debbie, puts his arm around her and gently  leads her out of the bank.
McCall and Forbes still have their rifles trained on the  bank door. Their police radio squawks...
The situation is secured. Suspect in  custody. Repeat. Situation secured.
McCall lowers his rifle as Roper guides Debbie through th wave of cops rushing into the bank.

Roper is exiting the bank and putting back on his gun whe he hears the sound of a CAMERA SHUTTER. He turns to see  VERONICA (RONNIE) TATE holding the camera. She snaps one Roper with Earl in the b.g. being placed in a squad car.
There's one for the front page.
Roper puts his hand over his heart as if stricken with lo which he in fact is.
Ronnie, why are you torturing me? I  can't live without you.
Ronnie rolls her eyes. She doesn't take Roper all that  seriously.
Don't start.
She slings the camera over her shoulder and starts to wal off. Roper dogs her.
This baseball player you're going  out with... (shaking his head) He's no good for you.
Really?! He's a wonderful guy. He  makes two million a year, and he  worships me.
I worship you.
You worship yourself.
Ronnie, forget this what's-his-name.
Greg.
Did you know he's already got a bad  knee? In another 10 years you're  going to be pushing him around in a  wheelchair.
Ronnie stops. Looks him in the eye.
You know what I think? I think you  only want me now, because I'm with  somebody else.
Who cares what you think. I want you  back and that's all that matters.
Ronnie smiles, but offers no response.
Let me take you out tomorrow night...  Pleeease.
I'm going out with Greg tomorrow.
(frowning) This Greg is really getting in my  way.
Roper gets down on his knees.
Please. I'm begging you.
Oh, I've got to get a shot of this.
She takes the lense cap off her camera. Roper primps his  hair to make sure he looks good for the picture... CLICK! Suddenly Roper notices that his Trans Am is being towed. rushes over to his car.
Hey, that's my car.
A REPO MAN stands off to the side watching dispassionatel
Not anymore. Now it belongs to Silver  Hills Financial.
Roper sadly watches the tow truck drive off with his belo Trans Am.
Lots of activity. Officers in cubicles; talking on phones typing reports on computers. Most are plain-clothed. Rope weaves through the room. Passes by Baffert's desk.
Hey, Baffert, what's the story for  tonight?
Baffert pulls two tickets for the Warriors' game out of h pocket.
Floor seats.
You're my hero.
Dinner's on you.
Deal.

A quiet contrast to the squadroom. This is the executive  branch of Metro. All the big-wigs are officed here. Roper walks down the carpeted hall. No one here except Kevin Mc quietly sitting outside Captain Solis' office. Roper and  McCall make brief eye contact. Roper thinks nothing of it He goes into the Captain's office.
CAPTAIN FRANK SOLIS is on the phone. There's a file on th desk in front of him. He motions Roper to sit down.
He just walked into my office. (looks over at Roper) The Chief says, "Good work this  morning. Congratulations."
Roper smiles as he sits down.
Tell him to give me a raise.
(into the phone) He says, "Thank you very much." (a beat) I'll discuss it with him right now...  Good-bye, Chief.
Solis hangs up. Looks across the desk at Roper. A long pa He knows he's got leverage.
Roper.
What?
Are you going to make this hard for  me?
Depends. What's up?
There's been some concern about you  continuing to work without back-up.
Define concern.
Solis dumps his cards on the table.
What if you die and no one can do  what you do as well as you do it?
Your concern is heartwarming.
It's been decided that you take on  another partner and train him to be  able to take over for you.
Is that what the guy in the Sunday  School suit is doing outside?
His name's Kevin McCall. Every Metro  Captain agrees that he's their top  sharp-shooter and most likely to  succeed.
Roper grabs McCall's folder off the desk.
Let me see that.
Roper scans it.

Tested high on his intellectual  aptitude... Not as high as me but...  National marksman finalist... Attended  N. Y. C... Went to college. Very  impressive. F.B.I. sniper school...  Mayorial commendation.
McCall turns around in his chair. He can see Roper and So through the glass walls of the office, but he can't hear  their voices.
"Additional Skills": Biathelete,  marathoner, lip-reading, speaks  Spanish...
Roper throws the folder back on the desk.
Great, send him to the Marines. This  guy's not a negotiator. He'll quit  in two weeks.
You let us worry about that.
Is there going to be an expression  of your appreciation?
(gloomily) What kind of appreciation are we  talking about?
The financial kind. I figure I'm  going to be working extra hours. All  sorts of overtime... training  sessions... Not to mention the extra  stress...
What do you think would be in order?
Like ahh... I don't know... (boldly) Five thousand dollars.
(calmly) Okay, I think I could swing that.
Uh-oh, Roper thinks maybe he sold short.
(quickly) And a car.
Hey, you just got a five thousand  dollar raise. Get a car of your own.
You know you've got nothing but cars  down there in impound.
Impound isn't a rent-a-car company.
(firmly) The car is part of the deal.
What happened to your Trans Am?
Solis gets up and taps the glass, motions for McCall to c in.
Repoed this morning.
(relenting) I'll provide you with transportation.
And even if this doesn't work, I  want all the money. These SWAT guys  don't have the temperament. They  don't have the background...
McCall enters the office.
(instant character  change) Hey, glad to meet you. I've heard  nothing but good things about you...
Roper reaches out. They shake hands.
Same here. I've watched you in action.  Very impressive.
You've got a lot of hard work ahead  of you if you want to be a negotiator.
I'm ready to do it. (a beat) And I'm going to be here more than  two weeks.
Roper's face darkens.
Don't go reading my lips, man. That's  an intrusion. Save that shit for the  sniper school. Comprende?
Sorry... Habit.
(intervening) Let's move past this, gentlemen.
Roper smiles.
We're already past it, aren't we,  Kevin?
If you say so.
Then you'll have to excuse me. I  have other work to do.
Roper and McCall head out the door.
Roper...
Roper turns back around.
About the transportation issue...  You check with the impound sergeant.
Roper smiles. Total victory.
MOVING with Roper and McCall.
You ever been in a hostage situation?
Only at the very end.
How do you feel after a shooting.
(self-assured) Like it had to be done.
They enter the squadroom, wind through the cubicles.
It rarely has to be done.
I've rarely shot anyone.
SWAT is a lifesaving unit, you know.
(flatly) I know.
Try to remember that.
They arrive at Roper's desk.
Okay, "Dead Eye", lesson one...
Roper grabs an empty soda bottle from a neighboring desk. takes the cap off a ball point pen and drops it into the  empty bottle. He places the bottle on his desk.
Extract that pen cap without touching  or moving the bottle.
McCall looks at the bottle quizzically.
What's the point of this?
A little exercise in lateral thinking.  The obvious solution isn't always  the only solution... See you tomorrow.

Roper grabs his jacket and walks off, leaving McCall to p the problem. McCall looks over at another cop who has bee observing. The cop shrugs his shoulders. He hasn't got a  clue. McCall sits down and thoughtfully peers into the bo
Sequence omitted from original script.
Roper and Baffert walking past the row of cars, including Solis' cadillac, searching for Roper's "new" transportati Roper is holding the keys in his hand.
Mind if we make a stop on the way?  We busted Frank Antonucci on  possession. He gave us a lead on  that Polk Street jewelry heist.
"Phoney Frank"? Don't waste your  time. He'd tell you his granny was  in on the Kennedy assassination if  he could dodge a collar.
I still gotta do it. Wasting time is  half my job.
Yeah, okay.
Roper is looking at the numbered parking spaces.
This SWAT guy might be a good idea.  He may be able to take a little  pressure off you. I worry about you.
You worried about me, too? The chief's  worried about me. Solis is worried  about me. Maybe you guys should start  some kind of organization.
Speaking of which. I saw you talking  to Ronnie this morning. Why can't  you get it back together with her.  You've gotta be out of your mind not  to get with that one.
It's not me. It's her. She's going  out with this baseball player --  Greg Barnett.
(impressed) No shit! He's good!
Fuck him. He swings at anything in  the dirt. I could strike him out.
Don't give up on her. You're getting  to the age when you ought to be  thinking about these things.
Roper bends over like an old man.
Yep, my rheumatism's been acting up.
They arrive at their destination. A parking space with a  1957 DODGE PICKUP.
This is it. Space 742.
Roper looks at the pickup truck in disbelief.
Then he didn't say 742. He must have  said 724 or something, because this  can't be right.
Baffert unlocks the pickup and offers the keys to Roper w is crossing to the truck.
Oh man! What am I, Red Foxx? I'm not  riding in this shit. I can't roll in  no shit like this.
He takes the keys from Baffert who moves around to the  passengers side. He opens the door.
Where's the stereo?
Fuck the stereo. What's that smell?
Come on. Just get in. We gotta go.
The pickup in traffic.
Sequence omitted from original script.
It's a four story twenties style walk-up. It's evening no The pickup pulls to a stop out front.
Baffert pulls out a slip of paper.
Apartment 306.
You want me to go up with you?
Nah, It probably won't turn up  anything. I'm just gonna talk to  him.
Good. I don't want to be late.
Baffert gets out. Roper grabs his cell phone.
You want anything on the game?
Baffert turns back around.
What's the line?
It was Warriors plus 6 this morning.
I'll take half of your action.
Baffert goes into the building. Roper dials his cellular  phone. Beep! Beep!
A message on the display reads: RECHARGE BATTERY. Roper looks around. There's a payphone across the street. gets out of the truck and crosses to it.
Third floor hallway. Nice, middle class place. Well kept Baffert walks over to room 306. Knocks.
Jazz is playing. MICHAEL KORDA sits motionless in a chair listening to the music. There's a KNOCK. Korda responds a if pulled from a trance. He rises and moves to the door.
Who is it?
It's Lieutenant Sam Baffert from the  San Francisco Police Department.
A slight hesitation from Korda. He glances around the  apartment. For what reason, we don't know. Maybe to make  sure there's nothing incriminating around. He opens the d
What happened? Is there a problem?
May I come in? I would just like to  ask you a couple of questions.
Korda steps aside and lets Baffert enter. Korda closes th door. Baffert scans the place. Not bad. He listens to the music. A smile grows on his face.
Count Basie?
Korda smiles back. Another jazz aficionada.
Duke Ellington. "Things Ain't What  They Used To Be", recorded July 30,  1945.
Yeah... Yeah... Now I can hear it.
Korda goes to the stereo, turns it down. Duke Ellington p low.
Where did you find an old recording  like that?
Used record shop down on Turk Street.  I was in there looking for some Robert  Johnson. (searching for the  name) Memories... Memory Lane or  something...
I've got to stop in there... Mr.  Korda, do you know Frank Antonucci?
You mean Frank who owns the bakery  down the street?
Baffert smiles.
No, this is a different Frank. This  is a man who deals in jewelry. Stolen  jewelry usually. You wouldn't know  anybody like that?
Korda drifts to the other side of the room. Takes a look his front window...
Nobody there. Just the truck.
I certainly wouldn't.
He says it as if the very idea disturbs him. He turns awa from the window. Baffert feigns a coughing spell.
Could I please have a little water?
(the perfect host) Of course.
Korda heads toward the kitchen area. Baffert uses this as opportunity to drift around the room. Do a little snoopin
The reason I'm asking you is because  we arrested him with some stolen  jewelry. It was traced to the robbery  of a store down on Polk Street. He  said he was fencing it for you.
Baffert notices something in the trash can.
Several glassine envelopes used for raw jewels. They have jeweler's markings on them indicating gem weight and grad
Korda, pouring the water, notices Baffert's discovery, bu his face betrays nothing.
(calmly) There's obviously some mistake. I  have a cousin who has had run-ins  with the law.
Korda re-enters the room with the glass of water.
Perhaps for his own reasons he  entangled me in this... situation.
This cousin of yours... What's his  name?
(forthrightly) Clarence Teal.
They look at each other a beat. Korda is still holding th water.
Your cough seems to be better.
A real repressed tension here. Someone's about to get hur Baffert takes the glass of water.
Thank you.
He takes a sip. Korda watches him like a cobra. Baffert p the glass down on the table.
Well, I'm on my way to the game. I  appreciate your cooperation, Mr.  Korda.
Korda smiles. Baffert walks to the door. Opens it to leav
Lieutenant...
Baffert turns back around.
Do you believe that story about Robert  Johnson...? That he made a deal with  the devil at the crossroads?
Baffert muses along with Korda.
Could be.
Baffert moves off down the hall and Korda closes his door
Baffert gets into the elevator.
Baffert takes out his cell phone. Dials.

(as the elevator  descends) Hello, Judge Stone... This is  Lieutenant Samuel Baffert. I'm at a  suspect's residence. I'm requesting  a telephonic search warrant in  connection with an armed robbery at  a jewelry store. There's visible  evidence on the premises. Glassine  envelopes with jeweler's markings  were seen in the trash can...
The elevator hits the first floor.
...I believe a full search of the  premises will turn up some stolen  property...
The elevator opens. Korda is standing there with a knife. Baffert has no time to react... The knife hand slashes forward... Stabbing the chest and  slashing across the throat.

Korda calmly exits the building as Roper crosses the stre returning from the payphone. Neither of the men take any  particular notices of each other. A WOMAN carrying her  groceries enters the building. Roper gets to the truck. A SCREAM from inside the buildin

Baffert is laying in the open elevator, knife wounds to h neck and chest. Roper rushes over to him. It doesn't look good. The woman with the groceries is standing halfway up the f flight of stairs. Frozen. Roper pulls out his gun and rus by her up the stairs.
(to the woman) Get an ambulance!
Roper arrives at the top of the stairs. Korda's door is a Duke Ellington can be heard faintly.
Roper nudges the door open, takes a step inside, gun read No one there. Suddenly, from the hallway, the click of a  door. Roper races out.
Roper sprints to the door at the end of the hall, KICKS i open. Gun aimed.
A five year old stares up at him. Scared stiff. Roper hol up a reassuring hand, and, as quickly as he arrived, he  leaves.
Roper burst out the front. Down the stairs to the sidewal Looks both ways down the street... Realizes in dismay tha Korda is long gone. A SIREN approaches.
Angle outside window to Roper sitting in a chair by the w looking out to the rain. Solis is in the b.g. on the phon
(on the phone) Yes sir. Every resource will be  brought to bear. We will find this  guy... Yeah, he's here now. I'll  tell him.
Solis hangs up the phone.
The chief says to tell you how sorry  he is. He knew Sam Baffert was a  good man.
(still looking out  window) He said he was just going up to talk  to him. He said... (beat; turning to  Solis) I want to be put on this case.
I can't do that.
(emphatic) I want to be put on this case.
You know I can't assign you to this.  You're much too close to it. You  were much too close to Sam. The  department will take care of it.
Who's running it?
Roper...
Who's running it!
Kimura and Glass will head the  investigation.
Roper turns to leave.
Scott. Go home. Get some sleep.
Roper pauses at the door. Then pulls out two basketball  tickets and lays them on the table in Solis' office. He e
Two detectives. A female named KIMURA and a tall guy name GLASS, try to make a getaway as they see Roper coming.
Hey, hey, hey...
Roper intercepts them.
Anything on Korda so far?
Solis said to keep you clear of this.
Roper responds louder than necessary with a half turn tow Solis' hallway.
I don't give a damn what Solis said. (to the detectives) If you get a lead, I want to know.
Sequence omitted from original script.
Roper's pickup drives by.
Thru the windshield. We see Roper as the windshield wiper flap back and forth. His face seems dazed and lost.
Roper knocks. Ronnie's cheerful voice can be heard.
Just a minute.
Roper makes no effort to pull himself together. The door  opens and Ronnie's face registers surprise. She's dressed casually in jeans, a nice shirt, but wears make-up and  earrings.
Hey.
Hey yourself. Came by to see Troy.
(like hell) A little late for that, Scottie.  He's asleep. (smells his breath) Jack Daniels?
I'm not drunk. Yet.
Maybe you should be.
You heard.
She nods, sympathetic, but doesn't leave the doorway.
Yeah. I'm sorry.
Can I come in?
Ronnie opens the door reluctantly.
Roper enters. Instantly we see he's at home here. He hang his coat in the closet, puts his keys on the table, notic a photograph on the wall. Quite imposing. Very unique sty
That a new picture?
About 4 months old. I'm working in a  new style.

Roper. Metro Division. Hostage  Negotiator. Give me the short version.

I know my job.
At that moment, a scream echoes down from the third floor window. Roper heads for the front door of the building.
McCall bounds up the stairs of the building to the roofto
The screams are getting more panicky. Roper comes down th hall quickly. The door to the apartment is open. It's bee that way since the guy in the green slacks fled. Roper hu toward the door.

The WIFE is in bra and panties and the HUSBAND is 6'4". H giving her a good beating. It's a studio apartment. Unmad bed. Belongings strewn all over. Window open with sun  streaming in, and a good view of the building across the  street. We hear ROPER'S VOICE from out in the hall.
I'm coming in. I'm not armed.
The husband snatches his wife by the hair and holds a kni to her throat.
(shrieking) No, Raymond!
(to Roper) Stay the fuck out of here!
But Roper steps into the apartment. Sees the wife. Face  swollen. Knife to her neck. The enraged husband, contempl murder. One inch from committing the act. Roper doesn't b an eye.
I know how you feel, Ray.
You don't know shit, and I suggest  you leave.
He presses the knife against the wife's throat. She wince Her chest heaves.
I can't leave, Ray. It's part of my  negotiator's oath. Once I'm in the  room with the hostage, I have to  stay.
You don't want to see what I'm going  to do to her.
Let me show you something, Ray.
Roper reaches into his pocket and pulls out his wallet. H extracts a photo.

holds it up so Raymond can see it.

I ain't interested in your life story.
Because I was partially to blame. I  wasn't around as much as I should  have been. I forgot how to love her.
She's the one to blame. Not me.
In prone position. Rifle in hand. Eye to scope.
of Raymond's open window.
Everyone where we left them. Roper looks at Ray with utte sincerity.
Ray, think about how she looked when  you married her. Think about how  happy you were. Don't lose that,  man. Don't give up everything.
What am I giving up? I'm laid off  last year. I'm down to my last  unemployment check. I'm out on the  streets looking for work and this  bitch is banging some asshole in my  bed.
And now Ray is crying. Blubbering actually. And he's not  that coherent.

I'm down at Consolidated and I'm  begging. I'm saying I'll take half  my pay. Eight years, man. I don't  even have to work the loading docks  anymore. I'll do maintenance. "We're  cutting back. We're streamlining,  Ray. West Central's running things  now. It's out of our hands" Fuck  them! Fuck them! FUCK THEM! (deep sigh) I'm gonna kill her and then I'm gonna  kill myself, 'cause I don't wanna  live anymore.
Roper reaches out to him.
Ray, if you walk out of here with  me, I'll get you a job.
Doing what? Cleaning toilets?

Who the fuck are you, Mother Teresa?

Ray stares blankly at Roper's outstretched hand, the knif clutched tightly in his fist... The wife squeezes her eye closed. Everything waits for an excruciatingly long beat. Then...

He rushes over to Ray. Circle of blood soaking into the  carpet. Ray's empty eyes. His hand still wrapped in his c He was dead instantly. WHO THE FUCK DO YOU THINK YOU ARE?

(still angry) You think I've never had a gun pulled  on me?! You think every fucking time  someone pulls a gun they use it?!

Eighty-five percent of domestic  disturbances of this nature end in  murder/suicide.
(fiercely) Not the ones I'm at.
McCall and Roper glare at each other. Toe to toe. A beat. McCall's face softens just perceptibly.
Sorry. My mistake.

We see each other every couple of  months.
Every couple of months, huh?

Where did you hear that?
Around. Barnett's tough competition.

You think you can learn, McCall?

It's a training room. It's built to approximate a conveni store. Several mannequins are placed around the room to  represent a hostage situation. The "BAD GUY" has a walkie talkie strapped around his neck. Roper's voice CRACKLES o of it.
What the fuck do you think is going  on, turdhead? I'm about to waste  everyone in this place.

H... how can I help you? Tell me  what... (looks off to his  right) I feel stupid talking to a dummy.
Roper enters the training room from a side door. He's hol the other walkie-talkie.

First things is, don't say, "What's  going on?" Everybody knows what's  going on. I come into this situation,  I say, (addressing the  mannequin) "I'm glad to see nobody's hurt. That's  good. I'm here to help you." (turns back to McCall) Second: You hesitated. Don't hesitate.  If you're thinking, talk while you're  thinking, or else he's going to think  you're plotting. Which you are. If  he thinks you're plotting, you're  going to make him nervous. You don't  want him nervous. Got that?
No.
It'll come. Try again.
ANGLE ON THE DOOR. McCall comes in. The room has the same set-up. McCall takes a look around. Launches immediately  into...
My name's McCall. I'm a hostage  negotiator. I'm here to help you.
Roper's voice crackles back at him hostilely.
How are you going to help me?
McCall's confidence is growing.
Tell me what you need.
I need you to bring me the scumbag  who ran off with my wife so I can  cut off his nuts.
Now he's stumped.
(hesitantly) I can't do that.
Then get out of my face you worthless  piece of frogshit.
McCall looks up to his right.
Is all the name calling necessary.
Roper re-enters the training area.
Nah, I just throw that in because I  enjoy it.
(exasperated) So what do I say to this guy?
You could say something like, (addressing the dummy) "Tell me what the scumbag's name is.  Maybe we can work something out."
What? Bring somebody in so he can  cut his nuts off?
Roper turns to McCall.
If you want to be a successful  negotiator, you've got to learn to  lie.
I'm not good at lying.
Get good at it.
It's against my nature.
Roper gives him an amused smile.
You know the ten commandments?
Yes.
What's the first commandment?
Thou shall have no other God before  me.

You tell me.

Yes.

To save lives.
So why would you hesitate to lie to  save lives?

Let's try it again.
McCall comes through the door. Hands in the air. The setu in the room has been changed a bit. The bad guy is behind the counter. Several hostages in various positions on the floor.
My name's McCall. I'm unarmed.
Okay, stop.

Close your eyes.

What did you see?

(rapid-fire) A dirtbag behind the counter holding  a sawed-off. A Berretta nine  millimeter in his belt. A female  hostage, red dress, on the floor in  front of the cereal display. Male  hostage, jeans and blue checked shirt,  three feet to her right. Another  male hostage, white pants, green  shirt, Nikes, laying in front of the  magazine rack. A female dirtbag with  a gun under her shirt, sitting against  the beer cooler, trying to pass  herself off as a hostage, and there's  a special on toilet-paper, four for  a buck twenty-nine.

Very good. You've got good eyes.  That's important.

Roper and McCall are sitting in the dark watching a video tape. It's grainy footage of a hostage situation in a spo goods store. A negotiator confronted with a gunman holdin ten year old girl hostage. The negotiator holds his hands out imploringly... Carefully moves toward the gunman. Was that your partner?
Roper nods.
Why did he do it?

(quietly) Because he knew the little girl had  zero chance of survival and his  chances would be a little better...  We had a plan, but SWAT opened up  too early. He got caught in the  crossfire. (a sad beat) Let's move on... Notice this. Always  use the eyes to keep the connection.  It almost like hypnosis. That's the  most important thing. Create a  connection. You're always on their  side...

Beautiful day. Roper and McCall leaning against the rail the walking ring. The horses are being paraded and saddle Roper scrutinizes them with an expert eye. McCall seems  totally disinterested.

See the four horse. Dropping in class.  No works. Front wraps. Looks like  he's broken down. But notice the  woman in the sun hat. She's the owner.  She wouldn't have come if her horse  was broken down. He's live. We use  him.

Okay, we're in good shape. We're in  good shape.

They need to run first and second?

COME ON RUSSELL!... (to Roper) Who the fuck's Russell?!
The jockey!

The FOUR horse crosses the finish line in front. The SIX  horse is flying... Needs to beat one horse to be second.. He's running out of room... With one last surge he hits t wire and... It's too close to call.

We won!

(confidently) We won.

Yes!

See this. Solis has me driving the  shit-mobile, and he picked this up  straight out of impound for fourteen  grand. Probably worth thirty.
Police corruption. It's everywhere.
Roper and McCall enter. McCall joins the men who are stud the blueprint. Roper stands by Solis and listens, takes n of the poster of Tahiti. Looks inviting.
This will take time to setup. I'll  have to get authorizations. (he listens) Okay, you relax, and I'll --
Solis pulls the phone away from his ear. Joe has obviousl hung up.
What do we got?
32 minutes ago the silent alarm went  off, then the fire alarm. A unit was  a block away, and the suspect got  trapped inside.
Any verification on numbers.

We've only seen and talked to one  suspect. He calls himself "Joe".  There's two jewelers, two salespeople,  the manager, a security guard, and  an elderly woman. This particular  store is where they do a lot of  jewelry making and repair. They have  anywhere from 8 to 10 million in raw  stones on any given day, so they  sure as shit didn't just wander in.  They knew what they were coming for.
What have you promised them?
Just that I'd talk to my superiors.
McCall returns from checking out the blueprints.
Any good points of entry?
McCall shakes his head.
The place is designed to be a vault.
Roper picks up the cellular phone. It dials automatically

(into the phone) My name's Roper. How are you people  doing in there? (he listens) Solis is off the job now, Joe. I'm  the guy authorized to give you  whatever you want. (listens) That's right, but first I need to  come down there to talk to you.

We don't see anything but the suspect on the other end of the phone. He's wearing a ski mask and gloves. Totally  unrecognizable to the audience. We will find out soon tha he is, in fact, Korda. He appears very cool and collected
You don't have to come here.
Yes, I do. That way there's no  misunderstandings. I need to make  sure no one's hurt, then we can take  care of business.
A long pause... Then a bit sinister.
Alright, Roper. You want to come...  come.
Good. I won't be armed. We gotta  operate on trust here. We're going  to wrap this up and have you guys  out of here as soon as possible.
Roper clicks off the phone. He already doesn't like the s of this guy.

Roper, bulletproof vest, hands in the air, walks across t eerily deserted street straight toward the jewelry store. It's quiet now. The choppers have been pulled back. Roper reaches the sidewalk right in front of the store. K cracks the door open.
(warningly) Stay there.
Roper stops in his tracks.
I'm going to put my hands down, okay.
Roper slowly lowers his hands.
Everybody watching through the window.

Korda takes a half step out the doorway. The gloved hand  that is visible is not holding a weapon. The other half o his body is hidden inside the doorway. He wears jeans, a  black shirt, and black Nike tennis shoes. He stares fierc from behind the ski mask. There's no sign of fear in him.
Are you in charge, Roper?
Yep.

I want a car. Like a four wheel drive.  I want it in perfect condition. I  want a uniformed cop to drive it up  right here. I want him to leave the  engine running and walk to the end  of the street. Then we'll come out.  I don't want any remote control  devices in it. I know all the tricks.  If it's not in perfect condition,  and I mean if its even low on wiper  fluid, I'm going to kill somebody  and we're gonna start again.
Korda lets that sink in.
I want a plane waiting at the airport.  I'll tell them where I want to go  when I get there.
Is that all?
For now that's all.
You'll get it. But, Joe, I want you  to do something for me. Let me take  a look around inside. Make sure  everybody's okay.
No. You just do shit for me right  now.
Korda's eyes glare from behind the ski mask. He's an omin figure.
Joe, I'm doing a lot for you. I think  you could give me something to cement  the deal... One hostage.
I'll give you something.
Korda pulls a wadded-up handkerchief out of his pocket an tosses it to Roper. Roper unwraps the handkerchief.
It's a human ear.
In fifteen minutes it'll be a bigger  piece. I assume there are no  "misunderstanding".
Roper is as serious as we've ever seen him.
I understand you completely.
Korda disappears back behind the door.

Roper trudges back in. Things are more active now. Logist officers are making flow charts. Photos of the hostages a being posted on a bulletin board. Roper approaches Solis, McCall and the SWAT CAPTAIN who are anxiously waiting for his report.
(flatly) We're going to have to take this guy  out.
That draws a long silence. That's something Roper rarely  says.
Can't we wear him down?
Roper hands Solis the handkerchief with the ear in it. So eyes it with dismay.

I believe there's at least one  fatality in there already. The fire  alarm was probably set off by gunfire.  I believe he's working alone, both  from his conversation and the fact  that he wouldn't come out beyond the  doorway. He was holding a gun on the  hostages while he was talking to me.  His demeanor is calm and controlled,  that's what really scares me. The  other bad news is that he also  indicated a familiarity with our  techniques. (a beat) So, do you want to go in or wait for  him to come out?
McCall calmly offers his opinion.
Let him come out. Too many unknowns  in there.
Solis nods. That'll be the plan.
When we drive up the car, make sure  it's at an angle about three feet  from the curb. (to SWAT Captain) Put our best man "highground", Twenty  degree down angle.
The SWAT Captain motions and turns to one of his UNDERLIN
Have Anderson prep it and notify us  when he's on line.
The underling hurries off to take care of it. Solis looks Roper dejectedly.
I feel this thing going sideways on  us.
Roper tries to buck him up.
There is some good news. He's wearing  a ski mask, so he's protecting his  identity and hasn't determined to  kill all the hostages... (big pause) Yet.

The jewel thief pulls off his ski mask to reveal he is Ko His face is sweaty. Hair matted. ANGLE WIDENS to show fiv very scared hostages: A JEWELER, middle-aged, balding. Th male MANAGER, good-looking, thirties, three piece suit. T SALESGIRLS, nicely dressed, late twenties. A FEMALE CUSTO gray-haired Hillsborough matron. They are all seated agai the wall. There are two fatalities lying on the floor. Th guard and one of the jewelers. Korda points his gun at the manager and the other jeweler and motions to the dead bodies.
Drag them behind the counter.

The two men reluctantly get to their feet and commence th grim task. The two salesgirls watch Korda fearfully. The  older female customer seems to be in a lesser state of  reality. Her eyes are a bit far away. Korda moves over to the remaining display cases that have been looted. With the barrel of his gun, He SMASHES the g reaches in and picks out the jewelry. He dumps it in an o satchel already half-filled with packets of raw gemstones and gold chains. Suddenly, the older woman customer gets her feet. She seems fairly out-of-it. Maybe in shock. She starts walking toward the front door frowning with  dissatisfaction.
I'm not staying here another minute.
(panicky) No, Mrs. Dotson.
Korda rushes around the display case.
Come here, hag.
He grabs a handful of the woman's coiffed gray hair and d her away from the door. She shrieks. The manager takes a  step toward Korda.
Leave her alone!
Korda pistol whips her across the forehead and drops her  unconscious to the floor then turns the gun on the manage
You're a brave one, aren't you?
The manager glares at him. He's about Korda's size. He th about making a run at him.
(pleading) Sit down, Doug.
A long beat... The manager sits back down on the floor wi the other hostages. Salesgirl 1 is giving aid to the old  woman. Korda looks down at her.
If she's not conscious when it's  time to leave, I'll have to kill  her.
Korda goes back to the display cases to collect the rest the gems.
Cops clear spectators out of the way as a green FORD EXPL RUMBLES through the barricade and heads down the deserted street.

Roper and McCall at the window, attention fixed on the st The Explorer crawls to a stop in front of the jewelry sto Parks at a slight angle. The uniformed police officer get out, leaving the engine running, and walks off back to th barricade.
Okay. Time to give this fucker a  call.
Roper picks up the phone, waits. Everybody tensely watchi the store.
Sequence omitted from original script.
A sniper team watching the store from a third floor windo
Roper holding the phone. It's still ringing.
Another sharpshooting team. Poised. Waiting.
And still another sharpshooter team.
The phone is still ringing.
This fucker's not answering.
Just then, the front door of the jewelry store swings ope A spray of white vapor shoots out the doorway. Korda is  discharging a fire extinguisher.
There's your answer. He's smart.
He's cutting down the visibility.
And doing a very good job of it.
A thick cloud of white hangs over the sidewalk obscuring front of the jewelry store. Roper puts down the phone.
Come on. Give us one clean shot.
(into his radio) All positions, you have the green  light.
They're out.
Roper grabs a pair of binoculars.
Through the haze, we catch glimpses of the hostages circl around the figure in the ski mask. They slowly shuffle to the Explorer. McCall watches intently.
A sniper watches through his scope. Finger poised on the  trigger.

Low visibility through the haze. The figure in the ski ma wavers in and out of the crosshairs, shielded momentarily the jeweler, then he flashes back into the crosshairs. Th sniper tries to lock him in.
The figure in the ski mask leans slightly and Roper catch a glimpse of the hostage right behind him. Roper recogniz him instantly.
It's Korda.
McCall sees him now, too.
They switched clothes.
Roper drops the binoculars and grabs his police radio.
(urgently) Hold your fire! Hold your fire!
Too late. A SHOT rings out. The figure in the ski mask go down, hit by the bullet.
Shit! Where'd that shot come from?  Hold your fire!
More SHOTS ring out.

The white vapor cloud swirls. The hostages, spattered wit blood, scream and scatter. The figure in the ski mask lie dead on the sidewalk. Korda, dressed in the manager's thr piece suit, holding the satchel of jewels in one hand and his gun in the other FIRES back at the snipers. He grabs  salesgirl 1 and drags her into the Explorer.
Roper sees Korda move toward the car with one of the host
He's got the girl.
Damnit!
As Roper turns into the room he notices a set of keys on  Solis' desk.
(grabbing the keys;  to Solis) Are these yours?
Yeah, they are but...
(to McCall) Come on!
As Roper and McCall move toward the door...
Roper, what are you going to do?  Don't take my...
And Roper and McCall are gone.
...car.

Police come rushing onto the street. Guns drawn. The Expl ROARS off down the block. Roper and McCall burst out of t command center building, leap into Solis' Cadillac and te off after the van. McCall is behind the wheel.

The Explorer comes barreling toward it. Spectators scatte Two squad cars SCREECH up behind the barricades, trying t block Korda's escape. The Explorer PLOWS through the meta barricades. BASHES the squad cars out of the way. And scr off around the corner.
Sequence omitted from original script.
The Explorer careens up an alley and bursts into the cong traffic of a side street. HONK-SCREECH! A Toyota swerves miss it and broadsides a parked car. The Explorer fishtai off down the street.
The salesgirl is terrified. Korda checks the rear view mi No one on his tail... At first. Then the Cadillac comes  speeding up behind...
Roper and McCall have the Van in sight, about a block ahe Roper picks up the radio.
Suspect heading west on Sutter now  passing Jones. Can we get an  intercept?

R-32-David. We are proceeding south  on Hyde. Will intercept.
Korda has one eye on the road and the other on the rear v mirror. The Cadillac is making up ground.
a squad car SCREECHES into the intersection and smokes to stop. Korda jerks the wheel, pulls a SCREAMING right turn and heads up the hill.
